Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect crop yields, but the magnitude of the yield response to warming depends on the temperature at which crops are grown. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially under future climate change, even if the mean yield response to warming is positive. This variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses in major maize-exporting countries. Our results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance and the need for investments in adaptation. They also underscore the urgency of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe impacts of climate change. This study is based on a simple model, but it is consistent with the available evidence and with the results of more complex models. It is the first to quantify the impact of temperature variability on yield variability under climate change.

Herbivory is a major driver of ecosystem structure and function, but the extent to which different species of herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining trophic interactions and biodiversity in herbivore communities. They also suggest that L megaherbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large herbivore populations.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem, but the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load in the open ocean is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study also highlights the need for a better understanding of the global distribution of plastic debris in the ocean. This is a major challenge for the scientific community.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are consistent with the formation of the grains in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains are not the result of a later condensation process. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies have implicated α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in clinical trials in MSA patients. The results also suggest that caspase-1 is a promising therapeutic target in synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels and controls vascular function. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that must be able to rapidly and efficiently integrate multiple lines of information to control vascular function. The communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate information is poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The results reveal that the endothelium uses a small-world network topology to integrate information. The small-world network topology is characterized by short path lengths and high synchronizability. The short path lengths and rapid signal transmission are achieved by shortcuts via connecting extensions to nonlocal cells. These findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of vascular diseases and for developing new therapies. The results also provide a model for studying the communication network in other cell types.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identified 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for diverse types of natural products, including antibiotics, bacteriocins, and styrylpyrones. These results support the finding that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. Anxiety is a common psychiatric disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. Although anxiety is often associated with negative consequences, such as avoidance of social situations, it is also a fundamental component of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats and identify an important role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also demonstrate that pharmacological modulation of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens can alter social rank. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the use of a single material phase and the development of structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses through a free-form inverse design approach. The structures are digitally synthesized with multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct behaviors and seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The design space is expanded by the use of multiple material phases and the development of sophisticated deformation mechanisms. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with complex behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a prime example of a heterochronic system, where the timing of the switch from fetal to adult hemoglobin expression is controlled by a single gene, HbF. Here we show that a similar mechanism exists in human erythroid tissues. We demonstrate that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is developmentally downregulated in erythroid tissues and that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in primary human erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is mediated by reduced BCL11A protein expression and mRNA stability. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the hemoglobin expression pattern in erythropoietic disorders. The results also have implications for the role of IGF2BP1 in cancer. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. Ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells are largely unknown. Here, we show that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), two central regulators of lipid metabolism. We further demonstrate that SREBP1/SCD1-mediated lipogenesis is required for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells and suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. Our study also highlights the importance of targeting lipid metabolism in cancer therapy. This work has implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations, but failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated species. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We screened a library of 1,000 compounds for their potential to inhibit the bacterial ribosome. Based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome, we selected 100 compounds for in vitro testing. The best candidate was then evaluated in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study demonstrates the potential of computational drug design for the discovery of new antibiotics. It also provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The resulting architecture is able to adapt to different problems automatically, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed network architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many image-processing problems.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become increasingly common. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we compare the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. Participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. Our findings suggest that the use of electronic devices before bedtime may have important implications for our health and safety. Public health interventions are needed to reduce the use of such devices before bedtime. Our results also highlight the importance of the circadian system in the regulation of sleep and performance. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the impact of electronic devices on health and safety. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell responses, but its specific role in autoimmunity and tolerance remains to be determined. Here, we show that conditional deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CTLA-4+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. Notably, cell transfer of thymocytes de novo produced myocarditis, otherwise not observed in donor mice depleted in adulthood. Moreover, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell responses, but its specific role in autoimmunity and tolerance remains to be determined.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that beetles diversified in the Carboniferous, a period of high biodiversity that coincided with the origin of angiosperms. We also show that the evolution of beetle herbivory was driven by the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These genes were transferred independently to beetles twice, resulting in the evolution of specialized feeding habits, including leaf mining and wood and stem boring. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in a relatively stable environment, but that the evolution of specialized feeding habits was key to their success.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population and become more adapted to the environment over time. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the evolution of complex artifacts may be more complex than previously thought. This work has implications for the evolution of technology in general, and for the evolution of human culture in particular.

Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. They also provide a useful method for understanding the nucleation of other materials.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in computer science, but it has not been widely used in scientific computing. We show that this is because of the instability of DL algorithms in scientific computing. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can compute a stable neural network (NN) with a given accuracy. We also introduce a new class of stable NNs, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), and prove that they are optimal in terms of the number of layers needed to achieve a given accuracy. Our results have implications for the design of DL algorithms in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past pandemics. The 1983 study by the psychologist Daniel Kahneman and his colleagues is often cited as evidence of this failure. It is also often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information science and statistical physics. The interplay between them is a central topic of current research. However, a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics is still lacking for interacting systems. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability, quasiparticle picture, and a careful analysis of the steady state. Our findings are relevant for the study of quantum quenches in isolated systems. They also pave the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The brain is the most expensive organ in the human body. It is also the most complex. The evolution of brain size is often used as a proxy to study the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased because brain size is not the only determinant of the brain’s computational power. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only determinant of cognitive ability. We also show that the evolution of brain complexity is shaped by the evolution of the number of neurons.

The HSP90 chaperone family is implicated in a variety of cellular processes, including cell growth and death. The HSP90-interacting protein TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence for it in the real world is controversial. We test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed of Facebook users. When positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. It also has implications for our understanding of the causes and consequences of depression.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, and are maintained over time. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining characteristic of aquatic mammals. We test the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes through a quantitative analysis of the fossil and extant record. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in three of four extant aquatic mammal lineages. The aquatic lifestyle is also driving the evolution of larger body sizes in the fossil record of extinct aquatic mammals. These results are consistent with energetic constraints on the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals.

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of hydropower dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of intense research for the past three decades. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of proinflammatory factors, which are responsible for the activation of neighboring immune cells. These findings have important implications for AD treatment, as targeting the neuron may be a more effective strategy than the current focus on microglia. This study also provides a rationale for the use of Aβ-based vaccines in AD. Finally, our results suggest that the human brain may be a more vulnerable system than previously thought, since neurons are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ in the early stages of AD. This may explain the presence of a preplaque inflammatory response in the human brain.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, in which a system can spontaneously reach a critical state with a power-law distribution of activity. We describe the model and its relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen in human history is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution and spread remain largely unknown. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can maximize SOC storage on grassland-derived Mollisols remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not significantly increase SOC storage in perennial pastures. In contrast, rotational grazing of pastures increased SOC storage by 18 to 29% compared to continuous maize monocropping. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on Mollisols worldwide. Our findings have implications for climate-smart agriculture and the restoration of degraded grasslands. They also highlight the importance of soil microbial processes in SOC sequestration. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and cause disease in humans. We used this framework to prioritize 887 viruses, including 12 that have not previously been linked to disease in humans. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and control of viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies to mitigate their spillover and spread.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a highly favored trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. It also provides a new chemical scaffold for the design of novel colorants. We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of the sample also indicates that men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia.

The human genome is replicated by the Okazaki fragment mechanism, which requires the faithful duplication of DNA in the absence of a template. The lagging strand template is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive manner, but the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Our results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more similar to the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme than previously thought. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the Okazaki fragment mechanism. The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes have been used to synthesize RNA molecules, but their activity has been limited to short, simple sequences. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that improved the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is dated with a precision of ∼100 ka. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction, and the carbon cycle continued to be volatile for ∼500 ka. The extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will be of interest to a broad audience of geologists, paleontologists, and ecologists.

The chemical properties of atoms are essential for understanding the chemistry of compounds. However, the chemical properties of atoms are not constant, but depend on the pressure. We calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemistry of atoms under pressure. It is also a first step toward the understanding of the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. We show that human demography, through fire suppression and ignitions, can have a large effect on fire activity and carbon emissions. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. Our study highlights that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which host-derived nutrients are delivered to the symbiont’s habitat and how this delivery is regulated remain largely unknown. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many applications.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the climate in Asia and Europe was in a state of transition during the 14th century, which may have facilitated the introduction of the disease into Europe. Our results provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the disease was not introduced into Europe by a single event, but rather by multiple introductions. Our results also suggest that the climate in Asia and Europe was in a state of transition during the 14th century, which may have facilitated the introduction of the disease into Europe. Our findings provide new insights into the history of the Black Death and the spread of plague in Europe. They also have implications for the spread of other diseases in the past and present.

Sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is a rapidly spreading disease affecting populations of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Northeast Pacific Coast. We provide evidence that the virus is transmitted by the crown-of-thorns sea star (Acanthaster planci), and that the virus is present in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms. The virus has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y, suggesting that it has been present for a long time. SSaDV is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Language processing is a complex cognitive task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a major evolutionary event in the history of life on Earth. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought years is more than doubled if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive information. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be a promising therapeutic strategy. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Recombination is a fundamental process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are dynamically activated in a task-dependent manner. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin lineage leading to humans and Neandertals is relatively well documented from 200,000 to 40,000 y ago. However, the evolution of the human hand between 800,000 and 200,000 y ago is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record for the hominin lineage leading to humans and Neandertals. The fossil record for this lineage is poorly documented between 800,000 and 200,000 y ago. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for purine and thymidine synthesis. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. Cancer cells have both cytosolic and mitochondrial SHMT, with the mitochondrial isozyme strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. These inhibitors are effective in cancer cell-lines, but paradoxically increase cytotoxicity in a B-cell lymphoma cell-line. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell lymphoma. This study identifies a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. Deforestation is a major driver of biodiversity loss and climate change, but it is also a threat to people’s livelihoods and food security. In this study, we show that deforestation can affect people’s diets, and that this effect is mediated by the loss of natural landscapes such as forests. Our findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in strategies to improve food and nutrition security.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-million-year-old footprint of a sauropod in the same formation as the first evidence of subsoil compaction.
